Dust clouds. Gravity’s pull.

The term solar system comes from sol, the Latin word for "sun"—a star and everything bound to it.<[silence:2400]>

Most people picture planets orbiting a sun, but the real story starts with a cold, dark cloud of gas and dust—like a cosmic fog.<[silence:1200]> Deep inside, gravity slowly squeezes the cloud tighter, like a hand crumpling a blanket.<[silence:2400]>

The center heats up, igniting a star.<[silence:1200]> Meanwhile, leftover dust sticks together—first like pebbles, then boulders, then planets.<[silence:1200]> Some grow big and gassy, like Jupiter.<[silence:1200]> Others stay small and rocky, like Earth.<[silence:2400]>

Our solar system formed this way 4.6 billion years ago from a cloud called the solar nebula.<[silence:1200]> The proof? Meteorites—space rocks older than Earth—carry traces of that ancient dust.<[silence:2400]>

Not all systems look alike.<[silence:1200]> Some have two suns.<[silence:1200]> Others, like TRAPPIST-1, pack seven Earth-sized planets close together.<[silence:1200]>

Protoplanetary disks.<[silence:1200]>
Rogue planets.<[silence:1200]>
The first billion years.

The center heats up, igniting a star. Meanwhile, leftover dust sticks together—first like pebbles, then boulders, then planets. Some grow big and gassy, like Jupiter. Others stay small and rocky, like Earth. <[silence:2400]>
